94.70.text:
Almost 14 years ago,
I went to a sixth form college

101.98.text:
A levels are the
single-subject exams

104.40.text:
that most students
in England and Wales

107.18.text: sit to gain entry to University.

110.10.text:
Most people take three to five
of these; they're hard.

114.96.text:
On top of these subjects
we were taking,

117.46.text:
we were required to take
an enrichment class.

120.46.text:
This was supposed to be
a course in something

122.98.text:
completely separate
to what we were studying.

126.34.text:
The idea was to show universities
how well-rounded we were as students.

132.38.text:
My fellow students and I bemoaned
the fact that we had to do this.

137.38.text:
After all, it was extra work,
an extra class,

140.54.text: and attendance took up our time

143.78.text:
and it had nothing to do
with what we wanted to do

146.10.text: with our lives after all, did it?

148.80.text:
There were lots of courses
we could choose from.

150.92.text:
They included pottery,
life drawing, jewelry making;

155.20.text:
there were lots of sporty options
that I definitely wasn't interested in.

159.56.text:
And I remember
I selected the four least --

163.64.text:
well, the four least
unappealing from the list,

167.06.text:
because I didn't want to do any,
and I was soon notified

170.12.text:
that I'd been enrolled on
Introduction to British Sign Language.

175.94.text:
Since attendance was compulsory,
I went along to my first class

180.78.text:
and waited along with my classmates
for the teacher to arrive.

184.90.text:
The teacher arrived,
and I could only describe

188.12.text:
her appearance
as a little old lady.

191.60.text:
She was not what I was expecting
at all, but the thing

193.88.text:
that I wasn't expecting most
was that she was Deaf herself.

198.86.text:
I remember thinking, like,
"How is she supposed to teach us

200.88.text:
"if she's Deaf
and we can't understand her?"

203.36.text:
At the time, I had no
real knowledge about deafness,

206.64.text:
and I didn't know
any sign language.

209.69.text:
I remember, a student
who arrived late for the class

213.39.text:
walked in while the teacher
was writing on the whiteboard

218.92.text:
The latecomer walked in
and started explaining quite loudly

223.60.text:
how she couldn't find the room,
how she got lost.

227.68.text:
Of course, the teacher
didn't turn around,

229.68.text:
and we all uttered
in unison, "She's Deaf,"

234.40.text:
to which the classmate actually
started then apologizing

237.90.text:
quite loudly
to the teacher's back.

241.84.text:
I was so Deaf unaware at the time
that that late student could have been me.

247.20.text:
I probably would have done
something equally as silly, really.

253.40.text:
People like her, I would say,
aren't trying to be rude or exclusive --

257.60.text:
or, people like me at the time
aren't trying to be rude or exclusive,

260.98.text:
we're just so used to hearing
in a hearing world

264.18.text:
that we never actually
give a thought

267.34.text:
to what we'd do if we actually
met a Deaf person.

271.40.text:
And you might be wondering
how did she teach us, actually.

275.00.text:
And I'll try and strain
my brain back to remember

277.84.text:
because it was so long ago,
and she basically just

283.40.text: We sort of picked up signs.

288.50.text:
I don't know. I don't want to say
"through osmosis."

290.56.text:
It was a bit more structured
than that, but yeah.

295.30.text:
Maybe a sign language class
has to be experienced in person.

299.04.text:
I can't begin
to describe how it was.

302.50.text:
Okay. This is some information
about sign language.

306.06.text:
Before that first enrichment class,
I never really gave a thought

309.62.text: to what sign language might be,

311.96.text:
but I did think it would be close
to English in what it actually is.

316.42.text:
Just like there are many
spoken languages in the world,

318.92.text:
there are also many different
sign languages.

321.82.text:
Most people -- most hearing people
I tell that to are shocked.

325.24.text:
They assume that sign language
is the same all over the world

328.26.text:
and that Deaf people from all over
communicate with each other easily

334.82.text:
The thing is,
they're at least half right.

337.76.text:
Although spoken languages
in different countries

340.04.text:
can be markedly different,
Deaf signers don't usually have

346.86.text:
when using their native
sign languages with each other.

350.48.text:
British and American English
are I'd say at least 99% the same,

355.20.text:
proven by the fact that you're having
no problem following me so far -- I hope.

360.44.text:
But you'll be very surprised
to hear that British

362.44.text:
and American Sign Language
is very different.

365.92.text:
The two languages have
completely different alphabets.

369.80.text:
The American Sign Language
alphabet uses one hand,

373.00.text:
whereas the British Sign Language
alphabet uses both.

380.74.text:
because it goes further than that,
is that in BSL, there are also --

384.68.text:
British Sign Language, by the way,
BSL, -- there are also regional signs

389.76.text:
which can be thought of
a bit like regional dialects

395.30.text:
For example, "holiday,"
as in a vacation,

403.04.text:
is signed like this
in the north, seriously,

407.86.text:
whereas, in the south,
it's signed like this.

412.18.text:
"Holiday" -- sorry, because this is
"lazy" in the north of England,

415.18.text:
whereas in the south,
this is "lazy."

417.02.text:
I should actually move to the side
so you can perhaps see.

429.84.text:
I remember almost 14 years ago
when I was first learning BSL

434.84.text:
I was horrified at the thought
of these regional signs

438.26.text:
and by the thoughts
of the examiners for the BSL exams

441.85.text:
who would come from
anywhere in the country

444.17.text:
and ask me questions
using their regional signs.

447.44.text:
However, I soon found that these
regional signs were not a barrier.

451.53.text:
I found this because sign language
isn't just understood using the signs.

456.09.text:
It also relies heavily
on body language

458.54.text:
and facial expression,
as well as lip patterns.

462.30.text:
This meant that regional signs
weren't a barrier to me.

465.22.text:
I found I understood them
instantly a lot of the time,

467.74.text:
and even borrowed a few of them
from different parts of the country.

472.76.text:
Just as spoken language relies on
nonverbal feedback from a listener,

476.40.text:
particularly in a one-to-one
conversation setting,

479.58.text:
sign language users give feedback through
facial expression and body language

484.38.text:
to show that they're following
what is being signed.

487.02.text:
From what I've seen, this practice
seems to help Deaf people

489.74.text:
from different parts of the world
communicate much more easily

492.51.text:
than hearing people using
spoken and written languages.

496.92.text:
Just two weeks ago,
I saw two people in London

499.36.text:
communicating well
with their native sign languages.

502.80.text:
One person was British,
using British Sign Language,

505.28.text:
and the other was from Spain,
using their own local sign language.

620.22.text:
As we all know, diversity brings
massive advantages to businesses

624.50.text:
and communities, especially when
trying to solve problems.

628.98.text:
As it's been said, the best way
to solve a difficult problem

632.32.text:
generally is to get
a diverse group of people

634.88.text:
with diverse intellects
working on it.

637.98.text:
Computer programming
is full of solving problems.

641.16.text:
It's one of the main reasons
why I and many others enjoy it.

644.78.text:
It's finding creative solutions
to technical and logical challenges.

650.08.text:
And we all know that there are
many groups of people

652.26.text:
who are underrepresented
in our industry and communities.

656.08.text:
One particular shame,
in my opinion, when it comes to

659.02.text:
the underrepresentation
of Deaf sign languages users

661.42.text:
in programming is that they
could actually have a mind

665.94.text:
wired to give
an over-average ability

668.88.text:
to solve logical problems,
and could therefore be

671.42.text:
an extra-valuable asset
to any team or community.

So what, you know?
This is something I find fascinating.

something I've spoken

a finite number of neurons.

705.28.text:

708.08.text:

those neurons that would otherwise

711.46.text:

in audio processing

714.02.text:
"will be commandeered
by other parts of the brain.

717.16.text:
"This rewiring can enable
different parts of the brain

720.52.text:
"to form connections with
and speak to each other,

725.00.text:
"these connections lacking
in an average brain.

729.32.text:
"People with parts of the brain
which have connections

731.74.text:

are seen as having advantages:

739.68.text:

and logical problem solving --

And from that passage

what a Deaf sign language user

A couple of weeks ago

I called some on-site

Only one provider

to provide an interpreter

I asked if the interpreter

But the person I spoke to

because they had used

863.09.text:
to interpret

Also, coding boot camps

I contacted a few boot camps

879.28.text:
to provide for a Deaf

885.98.text: and out of the people I contacted,

since pair programming

900.38.text:
In London, I know many Deaf people
who pursue a variety of careers.

904.74.text:
One Deaf friend in particular,
Robert, isn't a programmer,

908.26.text:
but he has a very technical job.
He's very successful,

912.18.text:
and he has his own bespoke furniture
design and manufacturing business.

916.64.text:
He uses computer aided design,
and then programs --

919.40.text:
cutting and 3D printing machines
to produce his creations.

924.04.text:
I asked him recently how he
acquired his technical skills.

927.62.text:
He explained to me
that after leaving school,

929.94.text:
he got an apprenticeship
at a London museum

932.60.text:
making museum displays,
which is how he started,

936.72.text:
but to get to where he is today,
he's mostly self-taught

940.35.text:
by using a problem-based
learning approach,

945.20.text:
and occasionally finding
knowledgeable people to help

947.82.text:
when he's particularly
stuck on something.

954.30.text:
As you're aware,
I'm speaking at a Python conference.

959.36.text:
You might wonder why that is:
because Python would be a good language

962.78.text:
for a Deaf sign language user
to start coding in.

967.58.text:
I personally think so, and this is
a quote from a Deaf programmer

971.90.text:
I had online contact with,
and this person thinks so, too.

981.68.text:
Another Deaf programmer
I had communication with recently

986.58.text:
suggested another reason
why Python might be good

990.04.text:
for Deaf sign language users
to use while learning to program,

994.18.text:
and that is that there are
lots of visual libraries available

996.92.text:
in Python that connect
as a way into programming,

1000.76.text:
and Python could be picked up
on the side.

1014.94.text:
I recently went out for pizza
with a Deaf friend in London.

1018.68.text:
The waiter at the restaurant
had very poor Deaf awareness.

1024.04.text:
It was obvious to me
that he was embarrassed,

1027.92.text:
didn't want to look
at my friend as he talked,

1029.92.text:
and was all fidgety
and moved around more

1032.92.text:
while he was talking
than he probably would have done

1038.68.text: with a table of hearing people.

1042.30.text:
I think this was
out of embarrassment.

1048.38.text:
from what my Deaf friends
tell me, isn't unusual.

1056.52.text:
I asked some of my hearing friends
about how Deaf aware they are.

1060.34.text: None of them had any Deaf friends,

1063.36.text:
and they knew very little
about deafness and Deaf culture.

1068.54.text:
It seems that hearing people
don't mean to be exclusive,

1072.08.text:
but they don't know how to be
embracive of Deaf people either.

1077.30.text:
They often don't want to cause
an offense or embarrassment,

1080.72.text:
so instead of making an effort
when they see a Deaf person

1083.20.text:
at a meeting or party,
they steer clear,

1086.68.text:
and in so doing, they can actually

1090.18.text: that they are trying to avoid.

just won the Lemelson-MIT prize

Trying to sort of explain
the sentiment behind this,

1126.86.text:
I know I'm going to fall short

1131.26.text:
It's being like me ordering a dress,

1137.48.text:
only to find

that's a couple of sizes

Then I contact the shop

1148.94.text:
"that dress is perfectly sized

how is the hearing person

A while ago, I asked the leader
of a local meetup that I attend

1183.36.text:
what she would do if a Deaf person

She admitted that she

1193.06.text: So here are some communication tips

1204.90.text:
...basically generally any time
you might meet a Deaf person.

1209.12.text:
I'm going to do what I don't like doing,
which is reading from slides.

1213.96.text:
Make sure you have the person's
attention before you start speaking.

1220.82.text:
Try to use a place
with good lighting

1223.44.text:
so the person
can see your face clearly.

1227.94.text: Face the person and speak clearly,

1230.48.text:
using plain language
in a normal way.

1233.34.text:
Do not exaggerate
your lip patterns.

1235.44.text:
This is extremely unhelpful
for someone trying to lip read.

1239.90.text:
However, that is something
that a lot of hearing people do,

1247.40.text:
Check whether the person
has understood.

1250.32.text:
If they haven't,
try explaining a different way,

1252.86.text: just as you would do normally.

1256.72.text:
If you can't sign,
you can use gestures

1261.44.text:
many of which we actually use
when communicating with hearing people,

1265.04.text:
such as "please take a seat,"
or "would you like a drink?"

1271.82.text:
Do not shout.
Just as when you shout

1274.82.text:
at a hearing person,
it's aggressive.

1278.06.text:
If the person is a hearing aid user,
then it can also be uncomfortable.

1282.64.text:
The most important thing
is to make an effort.

1286.32.text:
Remember that Deaf people
are the experts

1290.42.text:
There are always many tactics to try
when an interpreter isn't available.

1298.28.text:
Some tips particularly for meetups
and conferences and such.

1303.50.text:
If possible, have both
sign language interpretation

1306.12.text:
and closed captioning
at conferences and meetups, too.

1311.52.text:
After each talk, attendees
usually gather for tea and snacks,

1315.36.text:
and also socialize and discuss
the presentation they've just heard.

1319.42.text:
It can be difficult
for a Deaf person to participate

1322.72.text:
in these conversations
with hearing peers.

1325.64.text:
Organizers should cultivate
awareness to ask speakers,

1328.54.text:
experts, open source contributors
to spend time

1331.48.text:
talking to Deaf attendees
during these times.

1337.28.text:
At meetups where there are
practical sessions,

1339.58.text:
organizers should enable mentors
to sit with Deaf participants.

1342.98.text:
Remember that mentors don't
have to be organizers or speakers,

1347.20.text:
that they should be someone
matched appropriately

1349.46.text:
depending on the skills
of the participant.

1353.02.text:
If possible, share slides
and notes with Deaf attendees

1356.04.text:
prior to the talks to make it
easier to follow what is being said.

1360.38.text:
Deaf people who are in attendance
at conferences and meetups

1369.02.text:
People can be proactive
by inviting Deaf persons to talk

1371.92.text:
and give talks
to a Deaf user audience,

1374.90.text: perhaps as a Birds of a Feather talk.

those were actually tips
I was actually given

that I showed you earlier,

"hearing people reject the idea

1402.50.text:
"that signed languages
are valid and complex.

1405.58.text:

to try to understand us.

1408.84.text:

1412.46.text:

1416.86.text:
"with some flimsy excuse
to cover their insecurity.

1420.40.text:

1433.02.text:
I think that's quite sad, so should we,
like, not be that kind of person?

I've had the privilege

1511.76.text:
in all the different sign languages.
I recently followed one in ASL,

1517.60.text:
because I didn't know any --
I still don't know any --

1520.58.text:
and I noticed that from the
instructory video I saw,

1524.70.text:
some of the question signs
are different.

1529.20.text:
I think what is "what" in British
might be "where" in American.

1533.76.text:
I'm not sure. I can't remember.
See, I don't know.

1538.26.text:
Also, I'd recommend finding
what courses are in your area

1542.24.text:
if you'd actually like to go
and attend a course in person.

1546.48.text:
I think Google is going to be
your best bet for this.

1550.16.text:
Sadly, where I learnt to sign
now only teaches Makaton.

1554.48.text:
They've really cut back on the
sign language courses that they offer.

1560.08.text:
So, yes, I think that's
everything I need --

1562.30.text:
well, everything I'd like to share
right now. I'll be around after

1565.52.text:
if anyone wants to come
and talk to me. Be cool.

1578.52.text:
And this is last session,
so thank you for being here at Pycon,

1580.68.text:
and thank you again to Sarah
for this great talk.

1583.36.text:
So I think we'll be moving down
to the main hall now.
